173. Coen, (Mrs. F.C).
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. H. C. Coen
Address: Langan, Sask.
Birthplace: Denmark

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Chamberlain, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Denmark
For how many people did you prepare meals? Five
How far was it to your nearest store? 50 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Oatmeal, Sugar, Salt, Green Coffee, Beans

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lein Ritter
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 40¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1906

For how many people did you prepare meals? 5

How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Salt, Coffee, Beans

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Hard Red Spring
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 30¢
How much did you use graham flour? 10 lbs.
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 40¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Other? No
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs or 20 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 75¢.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwards.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz.
At what price? 35¢.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From the cows.
Butter? churned at home.
That was the price of butter? 12¢.
Did you keep eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Skim milk cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Quails.
And Rabbits.
How did you get fresh meat? Shot it.
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat?
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds? Quails.
For how long? As long as the season lasted.
What part did fish play in the family diet? Plenty of fish.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.
Kind? Fullbore.

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? .................. Green wood.

Where did you get your fuel? .................................... Cut it on the cliffs.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Coal, propane gas, electricity.

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Cellophane, Wrapping Paper, Plastic used instead of Cardboard and wrapping paper.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - Porridge & Coffee, & Bread & Gravy
Dinner - Soup, Prunes, meat, & Bread.
Supper - Bread & Porridge

In spring settlers moved in and more food was available.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

...........1904....Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Husband and myself,
Duck

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Came from Denmark in July 1906.
Only two or three families in district.
So much snow in winter trains could not come through, which made living conditions very difficult.
And food supplies scarce.
173. Coen, (Mrs. F.C.)

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

More prepared foods are available and more modern ways of cooking food.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still have a garden and use home grown products and also use purchased fruits, meat and canned foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Our greatest difficulty in early days was our ignorance of the country and climate. After the first year more and better food was available and we gradually prospered.
